awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Nanoscopy Of Surface States In Two-Dimensional Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Abstract: 
Rapid technological advances are often driven by the discovery of new materials and physical phenomena. Two-dimensional layered materials exhibit some of the most striking physical phenomena in modern materials research and hold promise for a wide range of future devices and technological applications from flexible electronics to energy harvesting and storage to bio-engineering. This project explores emergent electronic and excitonic surface states on layered two-dimensional crystals that arise due to the concerted many-body interactions at nanometer length scales. These investigations will advance our fundamental understanding of surface states that govern the electronic and optical properties of the next-generation nano-optoelectronic devices and the feasibility of two-dimensional nanolasers. These research activities are part of an integrated education plan to further high school, undergraduate and graduate students' nanoscience and nano-optics learning in the greater Atlanta area. The research is also integrated with outreach activities to enhance the education and training of local high school physics teachers and students as well as with community outreach plans that targets the educational experience of African immigrant students/families and African American youth in the Atlanta area.

Technical Abstract: 
The research part of this CAREER award explores the electronic and excitonic surface states on van der Waals layered two-dimensional crystals using state-of-the-art far-field and nanoscale near-field spectroscopy. The goals of this research are: (i) understand the fundamental properties of surface states in two-dimensional systems, metallic and conducting surfaces states and topologically protected surface states; (ii) understand the properties of excitons (charged and neutral) at island edges and defects and elucidate the coupling mechanism between excitonic two-dimensional materials and surface plasmons, in particular the mechanism of stimulated emission in excitonic van der Waals heterostructures made by vertically stacking atomic thin materials; and (iii) expand the scope and utility of optical, infrared and terahertz scattering scanning near-field optical microscopy approaches in the field of low-dimensional physics. The results of the proposed research will forward our underlying understanding of surface states that control the electronic and optical properties of two-dimensional emergent material systems and will lead to exotic many-body physics and applications in spintronics, practical quantum computers and solid-state quantum photonics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit: The aims of the research project were to explore the electronic and excitonic surface states on layered and 2D crystals transition metal dichalcogenides, black phosphorus, violet phosphorus and heterostrucutres. The experiments were performed using high-resolution infrared (IR) and optical scattering-type scanning near-field optical microscopy (s-SNOM). The research focused on several specific areas, including the study of spin-density modes (spin plasmons) on topological insulators, the investigation of metallic surface states in group-VI dichalcogenides, the study of localized excitonic effects and excitonic valley coherence spectroscopy at the edges and defect sites of single and multi-layer dichalcogenides and black phosphorus, and excitonic 2D surfaces with 2D plasmons. The research provided understanding of quantum confinement effects, the salient differences between bulk and few/single layers, and the effects of metallic surface states on the optical properties of vdWs and 2D material systems. We have also investigated a reconfigurable hyperbolic metasurface made of a heterostructure of isotopically enriched hexagonal boron nitride (hBN) in direct contact with the phase-change material (PCM) single-crystal vanadium dioxide (VO2). The study found that the polariton's propagation on hBN changes with changes of the VO2 phase. Polariton interaction on different substrates can significantly modify polariton dispersion. In summary, the research program included various studies on the electronic and excitonic surface states on layered and 2D crystals, surface and volume confined polariton interactions,  investigation of the stability of 2D materials under different environmental conditions, development of nano-spectroscopy and imaging techniques, development of computational modeling to calculate nanoscale dielectric functions of complex materials.

Broader Impact:

The proposed research aimed to investigate electronic and excitonic surface states on layered and 2D crystals using high-resolution infrared and optical scattering-type scanning near-field optical microscopy (s-SNOM). The research provided insight into the fundamental properties of metallic or conducting surface states and surface excitons, and their interactions. The research benefited education and outreach efforts by providing advanced multidisciplinary skills to undergraduate and graduate students, including those from underrepresented groups, and by integrating the research into outreach activities for high school physics teachers and students, as well as community outreach. The research enabled to recruit and support the inclusion of underrepresented minorities in meaningful research.

In summary, the research project has been very successful, resulting in 3 patents and over 20 publications, as well as providing training and support for a number of graduate, undergraduate and high school students and postdocs. Additionally, the progress made through this project has led to additional funding and opportunities, such as the NSF NRT grant to establish a quantum networks research and training program at the University of Georgia. Overall, the research has had a significant broad impact in the field and within the academic community.
